abstract.p: The significant advantage of ground mobile robots (GMRs) is their accessibility to areas that are inaccessible for humans. One difficulty of current GMR technology is that the external driving mechanisms, such as wheel, track, and leg, restrict its applications. In order to solve this limitation, the present paper proposes a novel driving mechanism using a novel GMR called the double-pendulum driven cart (DPDC). The DPDC, which employs only internal thrust and static friction, is capable of steering by two parallel pendulums mounted on the cart, and is able to implement planar elemental motions by designing the pendulum trajectory properly. The paper first studies the dynamic modelling and the motion control issues of the DPDC. A closed-loop controller using the partial feedback linearization technique is then designed for the tracking control of the parallel pendulums to guarantee accurate motion of the cart. Extensive simulation results verify the proposed model and the efficiency of the motion control strategy.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: A ground mobile robot (GMR) is a robotic device that is capable of moving on ground or over a rough environment. One significant advantage of GMRs is their accessibility to areas that are inaccessible for humans. This priority benefits GMRs in a number of applications that include, but are not limited to, space exploration [1, 2], rescue and recovery [3, 4], and medical endoscopy [5, 6]. During the past decade, abundant research on GMRs has focused on kinematic and dynamic modelling [7], motion and tracking control [8, 9], and localization and navigation [10]. In general, there are three types of GMR: wheeled mobile robots, tracked mobile robots, and legged mobile robots. They are respectively using active wheel, track, and leg as driving methods. Corresponding to the classification, there are three significant real-life issues for which research into GMRs has become a hotspot of robotics:

list-item.p: demand for an autonomous device which is dexterous to move on the ground and can serve disabled and elderly people;
demand for a robust device which is adaptable to highly dynamic environments and can be operated in a broad range of conditions, such as craggy and muddy terrains;
demand for a mimic device which imitates the motion of an insect or animal and can be employed in environments that are inaccessible for humans.

sec.p: The present paper mainly addresses the third point; it is inspired from the motion of a snake [11] and applies the idea to a four-wheel passive cart mounted with two parallel pendulums. However, a comprehensive modelling and motion control strategy are critical for the design and implementation of the proposed mechanism. Therefore, the current paper considers only the rationale, the dynamic modelling, and the motion control strategy of the resulting double-pendulum driven cart (DPDC) system.

With the increase of new applications, conventional GMRs cannot satisfy the exigent and specific requirements of industry and healthcare. One difficulty of current GMR technology is that the external driving mechanisms, such as wheel, track, and leg, restrict its applications. Simi et al. [5] proposed a novel design for active capsule endoscopy, using an internal actuating legged mechanism which interacts with an external magnetic field. Glass et al. [12] presented an actuated legged robot with an anchoring mechanism to enhance existing capsule endoscopes. Kim et al. [6] developed a locomotive capsule endoscope integrated with four external clampers based on the bio-mimetic approach. However these driving mechanisms are external, which is harmful to the gastrointestinal tract that contacts with the mechanism. This issue more or less motivates the originality of the present paper. Therefore, the paper aims to present a new concept of locomotion for GMRs which employs only internal thrust and static force, without any assistance of external driving mechanisms. The advantage of the proposed concept is that the wheels on the DPDC are embedded in a capsule [13], which will enhance its agility and flexibility, and enable its application in an uncertain environment. For example, a capsule endoscope with external driving mechanisms (legs or wheels) may have difficulty moving inside a human body without harming the patient. The proposed capsule has no external driving mechanism and can overcome this issue.

The DPDC is an extended system of the single-pendulum driven cart (SPDC) that has been studied for one-dimensional locomotion [14, 15]. The DPDC system proposed in this paper has four passive wheels and two parallel pendulums mounted on the pivots of the cart which are all embedded in a capsule [13]. By rotating the pendulums, internal thrusts are generated at the pivots which can drive the cart on a plane. The difference between the DPDC and the conventional GMR is that the former steers via internal thrust, while the latter steers via wheel rotation. Extending the SPDC system, the contribution of the DPDC system is that it extends the motion space of the proposed driving concept from one dimension (forward and backward motion) to two dimensions (planar motion). The present paper is devoted to studying the dynamic modelling and the motion control strategy of the DPDC system, and aims to demonstrate its capability to implement basic trajectories on a plane. In summary, this paper has the following contributions:

list-item.p: it proposes a novel DPDC system (to the authors’ knowledge, this is the first time this model has been developed);
the dynamic model of the proposed DPDC system is developed;
based on the dynamic model, the elemental motions of the DPDC system are obtained;
a closed-loop control algorithm using the partial feedback linearization technique is developed for the motion control of the DPDC system;
the dynamic model and the motion control strategy of the DPDC system are demonstrated using numerical simulation.

sec.p: The paper is organized as follows. In section 2, the dynamic model of the DPDC system is studied. In section 3, the system constraints and the pendulum trajectory are investigated. In section 4, the elemental motions of the DPDC system are studied in detail. In section 5, a trajectory tracking control method for the parallel pendulums is studied. Simulation studies and results are presented in section 6 and, finally, conclusions are given in section 7.

sec.title: 2.1 System description
sec.p: Suppose that the DPDC is placed on a plane surface with inertial orthonormal basis (Xo, Yo, Zo) shown in Fig. 1. A local frame (xo, yo, zo) is assigned to the cart at its centre of mass G. The coordinates of G in (Xo, Yo, Zo) can be written as G=(X, Y, Z). Since only the plane motion of the cart is considered, the Z-coordinate of G is constant. The cart moves on the plane with four passive wheels, and two parallel pendulums are driven by two torque motors mounted on the pivots of the cart at P1 and P2, respectively. In particular, the following assumptions are defined before the modelling:

list-item.p: the DPDC is a rigid system;
the weights of the four wheels, two pendulum rods, and two torque motors are negligible;
the two pendulums rotate only on the xozo plane;
the cart has no lateral skidding.

sec.p: In Fig. 5, the upper part shows the trajectories of the parallel pendulums and the lower part shows the cart trajectory along the Xo axis. It is seen that, in phase I, the parallel pendulums rotate quickly from −π/3 to π/3 which leads to fast movement of the cart along the Xo axis. In phase II the pendulums slowly reverse back to −π/3, which keeps the cart still. From the inset of Fig. 5, it is found that the cart moves forward fast and moves back a bit when the parallel pendulums induce large thrust in the fast motion, while it stays still during the slow motion due to static friction. Figure 6 shows the cart trajectory on the XoYo plane in five strokes. The cart finally moves forward 67.13 cm in 14.1 s, which gives the average speed of the cart as 4.76 cm/s.

sec.p: From Figs 7 and 8 it is seen that, as expected, the parallel pendulums rotate in opposite directions in five strokes, and the cart turns at its original position. In Fig. 7, the upper part shows the angle trajectories of the parallel pendulums, and the lower part shows the orientation of the cart on the XoYo plane. It is seen that the parallel pendulums are swung quickly in the fast motion which leads the cart to turn rapidly (ϕ increases dramatically). It is noted that the orientation of the cart also takes a short period to settle down, which can be found in the inset of Fig. 7. Figure 8 presents a visible turning of the cart in five strokes, which clearly shows the orientation is changed only at this stage. From the simulation result, it is found that the cart rotates 2.54 rad in 14.1 s.

sec.p: The trajectory parameters in Table 4 are used for curved motion, and the initial angle of the pendulum l1 is chosen at −π/4 for this case. The simulation results of five curved motions are shown in Figs 9 and 10.

caption.p: The trajectories of curved motion in five strokes
The curved trajectory of the cart in five strokes

sec.p: Figures 9 and 10 present the trajectories of curved motion in five strokes. It is seen that the cart moves in a curve due to the difference of the initial angles of the parallel pendulums. From the simulation results, it is found that the cart stops at (0.69, 0.14) on the XoYo plane, and has an angular orientation of 0.46 rad. The results demonstrate that the proposed model can perform a certain range of curved motions based on the rotation of the parallel pendulums. In particular, the curved motion can be controlled by the initial angle of the pendulum. This is an interesting problem that is not discussed in the present paper owing to space limitations.

sec.title: 7 Conclusions
sec.p: The present paper has studied the modelling and the motion control of the DPDC system. The DPDC system represents a new driving concept of GMRs which utilizes only internal thrust and static friction as driving forces. The novelty of the system is that it employs two parallel pendulums to drive the cart, and extends the motion of the cart from one dimension (forward and backward) [15] to two dimensions (planar). The following issues have been studied in the paper:

list-item.p: the dynamic model of the system;
the elemental motion planning;
the closed-loop tracking control of the elemental motions.

sec.p: Furthermore, extensive numerical simulations have been conducted to demonstrate the proposed model and the efficiency of the proposed motion control strategy. However, this paper has not considered practical experiments on the proposed system. Consequently, the practical implementation of the system is suggested for future work. Another important aspect for future work is to study and validate the proposed model (equation (17)) under various types of input (e.g. sin/square wave) from the system analysis viewpoint and the findings from such research will be reported in due course.
